question.title: How to figure out required Java version for a Maven dependency
question.body:
I am new to Maven. I am updating the libraries in an old Java 8 based project. I am guessing that when updating libraries, I shouldn't go for libraries that do not support Java 8 anymore.

How to figure this out easily? Right now, I'm googling for several versions of the libraries for the required Java base version to make sure that I pick the right one. Is this the correct way?

answers.body:
Here's the method I use to be 100% sure. I wrote this method that analyzes all the .class files inside a .jar file. When I need to know the minimum supported JRE major version for a given maven dependency, I download the dependency and feed the .jar file to this method and print the result.

You can obviously adapt this method to your needs.

public static int getMinimumJavaMajorSupport(String jarFilePath)
{
    int highestVersion = 0;

    try (JarInputStream jarStream = new JarInputStream(new FileInputStream(jarFilePath)))
    {
        JarEntry entry;

        while ((entry = jarStream.getNextJarEntry()) != null)
        {
            if (entry.getName().endsWith(".class"))
            {
                byte[] buffer = new byte[8];
                if (jarStream.read(buffer, 0, 8) != 8)
                {
                    throw new IOException("Unable to read the class file header");
                }
                int version = ((buffer[6] & 0xFF) << 8) | (buffer[7] & 0xFF);
                if (version > highestVersion)
                {
                    highestVersion = version;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    catch (IOException e)
    {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }

    return highestVersion - 44;
}

Example:

final int minimumJavaMajorSupport = getMinimumJavaMajorSupport("C:\\MyJar.jar");
System.out.println(minimumJavaMajorSupport);

Output:

17

question_comments.body: You can also look at central.sonatype.com, though contrary to mvnrepository.com, it only covers artifacts on Maven Central.

There is no way to find this easily. You need to go to the project for each library -if they have one- and check the documentation -if they have one- to see if they mention JDK version compatibility. Otherwise you need to do some guessing work based on the pom -if you have access to it- and the class version of the class files in the library.

@JFabianMeier Check what libraries are available in which version. Furthermore it shows in which Maven repos the libraries may be available and it provides direct links if you have the need to manually access the pom file or the library itself outside of maven. Furthermore it summarizes the CVEs for each library version and it is a nice UI for  looking up the dependencies. I know most of this can also be done using Maven itself but the command-line arguments you have to use are long are bad to remember.
@Robert I never thought of mvnrepository.com as something especially essential. What do you do there?
@mrig Why are you trying to update the libraries? If it is a Java 8 environment, why not leave it as it is?
@Robert - Interesting. I see that now. Even though my company doesn't allow that link to open but I guess it's little helpful. Still, it doesn't look like there is straight forward way for this.
Right now that will require lot of server environment upgrades as well which will be a bigger project for us. We plan to do that sometime.
Are you sure you don't want to upgrade the project to a newer Java version?

Search the library and version of the library on mvnrepository.com and then open it's POM file which is linked there. Usually the libraries contain a statement which Java compiler and target JRE to be used maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/examples/…
